--- title: "`janitor`: Clean dirty data, plus improved tables and crosstab" date: 6/25/23 categories: - data cleaning toc: true --- ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/setup_561f5ca5d1bb2174e51a7e91856a278a'} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true" code-summary="Setup"} library(janitor) ``` ::: [`janitor`](https://sfirke.github.io/janitor/index.html) contains various tools for examining and cleaning dirty data. ## Cleaning dirty data ### Clean column names Let's create a `df` with some poorly-chosen column names: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_4b268de502f4d61e6fe4840f101fd1f3'} ```{.r .cell-code} test_df <- as.data.frame(matrix(ncol = 6)) names(test_df) <- c("firstName", "ábc@!*", "% successful (2009)", "REPEAT VALUE", "REPEAT VALUE", "") ``` ::: `clean_names()` does just as the name implies: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_01dfd91172ede1f4b036438e856e10e2'} ```{.r .cell-code} test_df |> clean_names() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display}
|first_name |abc |percent_successful_2009 |repeat_value |repeat_value_2 |x | |:----------|:---|:-----------------------|:------------|:--------------|:--| |NA |NA |NA |NA |NA |NA |
::: ::: The `case` argument to `clean_names()` specifies what case you'd like output names to be in. You can specify any case style that's available in `snakecase::to_any_case()`, including "screaming_snake" if you want to be perverse: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_0901269dc1d76bb31830a57a10ed9dad'} ```{.r .cell-code} test_df |> clean_names(case = "screaming_snake") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display}
|FIRST_NAME |ABC |PERCENT_SUCCESSFUL_2009 |REPEAT_VALUE |REPEAT_VALUE_2 |X | |:----------|:---|:-----------------------|:------------|:--------------|:--| |NA |NA |NA |NA |NA |NA |
::: ::: ### Check if `df`s are row-bind-able Also useful is `compare_df_cols` which summarizes whether the specified `df`s can be row-bound (i.e., have columns of the same names/types): ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_ede269b16af52d466efc28d9702b1c80'} ```{.r .cell-code} df1 <- data.frame(A= 1:2, b = c("big", "small")) df2 <- data.frame(a = 10:12, b = c("medium", "small", "big"), c = 0, stringsAsFactors = TRUE) # here, column b is a factor df3 <- df1 |> dplyr::mutate(b = as.character(b)) compare_df_cols(df1, df2, df3) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display}
|column_name |df1 |df2 |df3 | |:-----------|:---------|:-------|:---------| |a |NA |integer |NA | |A |integer |NA |integer | |b |character |factor |character | |c |NA |numeric |NA |
::: ::: If you just want a simple `TRUE`/`FALSE` value telling you whether the `df`s match, you can use `compare_df_cols_same()`: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-6_d2bc0a894872c25e0db91148541183ad'} ```{.r .cell-code} str(compare_df_cols_same(df1, df2, df3, verbose = FALSE)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` logi FALSE ``` ::: ::: ## Examining data and crosstabs `janitor`'s version of tables are called `tabyls`. You can easily generate crosstabs: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-7_3875943f08e53eb5f5176706e55d6af2'} ```{.r .cell-code} palmerpenguins::penguins |> tabyl(species, island) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display}
|species | Biscoe| Dream| Torgersen| |:---------|------:|-----:|---------:| |Adelie | 44| 56| 52| |Chinstrap | 0| 68| 0| |Gentoo | 124| 0| 0|
::: ::: There are lots of ways to pretty up the output via `adorn_*` commands, giving things like column or row percentages, optionally with `n`s in parentheses: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-8_8d7b093a294300624a97b0e692249696'} ```{.r .cell-code} palmerpenguins::penguins |> tabyl(species, island) |> adorn_totals("col") |> adorn_percentages("row") |> adorn_pct_formatting(digits = 2) |> adorn_ns() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display}
|species |Biscoe |Dream |Torgersen |Total | |:---------|:-------------|:------------|:-----------|:-------------| |Adelie |28.95% (44) |36.84% (56) |34.21% (52) |100.00% (152) | |Chinstrap |0.00% (0) |100.00% (68) |0.00% (0) |100.00% (68) | |Gentoo |100.00% (124) |0.00% (0) |0.00% (0) |100.00% (124) |
::: ::: You can also use the `adorn_*` functions on regular ol' `df`s: ::: {.cell hash='index_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-9_4a45886879978ed991b803787e5b8ff4'} ```{.r .cell-code} palmerpenguins::penguins |> dplyr::sample_n(10) |> # <1> dplyr::select(-year) |> adorn_totals("row") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display}
|species |island | bill_length_mm| bill_depth_mm| flipper_length_mm| body_mass_g|sex | |:---------|:---------|--------------:|-------------:|-----------------:|-----------:|:------| |Chinstrap |Dream | 45.7| 17.0| 195| 3650|female | |Adelie |Torgersen | 35.9| 16.6| 190| 3050|female | |Chinstrap |Dream | 45.5| 17.0| 196| 3500|female | |Gentoo |Biscoe | 49.4| 15.8| 216| 4925|male | |Adelie |Dream | 39.7| 17.9| 193| 4250|male | |Chinstrap |Dream | 49.5| 19.0| 200| 3800|male | |Gentoo |Biscoe | 46.6| 14.2| 210| 4850|female | |Gentoo |Biscoe | 50.5| 15.9| 222| 5550|male | |Gentoo |Biscoe | 50.0| 15.2| 218| 5700|male | |Gentoo |Biscoe | 48.2| 14.3| 210| 4600|female | |Total |- | 461.0| 162.9| 2050| 43875|- |
::: ::: 1. Choose 10 random rows so this doesn't print forever Check out the [`tabyl`s vignette](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/janitor/vignettes/tabyls.html) for more info.
